textos_fuente.text:
Know Before You Go - Sarasota Medieval Fair 2025 The Festival General Info Welcome FAQ / Know Before You Go Information Map & Directions About Us Our Sponsors Contact Us Plan Your Vacation Accommodations Visit the Suncoast Entertainment This Years Theme Themed Weekends Shows Show Schedule Pub Crawl VIP Royal Treatment Explore the Festival Artisan Marketplace Festival Map Children's Realm Join The Fun Casting Call Celebrate Your Birthday Royal Weddings Volunteers Needed Accepting Merchants Contests Photo Contest Costume Contests & More! Media Room Buy Tickets Buy Tickets Know Before You Go / FAQ Helpful Hints - Beat the traffic! Arrive early! - Beat the traffic and enjoy our Opening Gate Ceremony at 9:45am.  Parking lots open at 9:00am.  Ticket booth at the gate opens at 9:30am. Gate opens and traffic builds by 10am. Opening Weekend! - If you prefer smaller crowds, join us opening weekend. Carpool! - Grab all your friends, turn up the tunes, and start your festival day together. Think Sunday! - Sundays typically have fewer crowds, especially when gates open. Print/Screenshot Tickets - If you order tickets online (recommended to save time and avoid the lines at the gate), print or screenshot your ticket email in case you do not have cell service at the park. Follow! - Go to our Facebook, Instagram, or X (formerly Twitter) page for real-time parking and traffic alerts. What is the Sarasota Medieval Fair? The Sarasota Medieval Fair is a recreation of a medieval era village with festive performers, crafts, demonstrations, games, rides, and food.  Each festival day offers exciting tournaments, scrumptious feasts, & pure family fun at our grand improved 47-acre home, the Woods of Mallaranny! Step back in time & watch full-contact jousting, human combat chess matches & other fantastic shows on 13 stages! Enjoy rides & play games!  Enjoy music & shop for the holidays in our artisan marketplace of over 140+ shops! Each festival weekend has a unique theme and a full line-up of unique acts!  Come one & all for all-around medieval family fun & merriment!  Huzzah! What are the festival dates and times? Saturdays & Sundays, November 1 thru 30, 2025, from 10am to 5:30pm, rain or shine. Where is the festival located? OUR 47-ACRE HOME!  Woods of Mallaranny (29847 FL-70 E., Myakka City, FL 34251). 
The Woods of Mallaranny offers 47-acres of stunning natural surroundings that will bring the fair to life. See our Map & Directions Page for more details. Is there a charge for parking? Parking is available for free.  Beat the traffic though and enjoy smaller crowds by arriving early, joining us Opening Weekend, or attending early on festival Sundays.  We also recommend carpooling.  RV and trailer parking is not permitted at the festival.  Huzzah! Can we wear a medieval costume? Our guests are welcome to wear medieval costumes suitable for a family-friendly atmosphere to get into the spirit of the festival!  However, costumes should be in keeping with the medieval era theme of the festival and we reserve the right to deny admission to or remove any person wearing attire that we consider inappropriate, too revealing, or attire that could detract from the experience of other guests.  We kindly ask that our guests please refrain from wearing futuristic or sci-fi related costumes that are not in keeping with the theme of the festival - while we have an absolute love and affinity for these genres, at the Sarasota Medieval Fair we prefer creating an immersive medieval era festival experience. Do I have to come in costume? Costumes are in no way required; comfortable clothes are recommended. Most of our guests do not arrive in costume but there are many who do.  While we feel that the whole experience is heightened and more fun when you come dressed to play, the choice is yours! What type of clothing is allowed at the festival? The Sarasota Medieval Fair is a family destination, and requires that guests wear appropriate clothing while in the park. This is an outdoor event, so you should dress casually with comfortable walking shoes. Proper attire is required for the duration of your visit to the Sarasota Medieval Fair. In order to maintain an environment suitable for guests of all ages, and in consideration of your personal health and safety, shirts and shoes must be worn at all times. Clothing depicting rude, vulgar, and otherwise offensive language or images is not permitted. Clothing in multiple layers is subject to search. We reserve the right to deny admission to or remove any person wearing attire that we consider inappropriate or attire that could distract from the experience of other guests. Guests in violation of our dress code will be asked to leave and escorted from the festival. What is the festivals weapon policy? Weapons of any kind, including guns, are prohibited.  However, if your costume includes a sword, or dagger it may be permissible as long as these decorative weapons are properly sheathed and peace-tied.  Present yourself to security personnel at the festival entranceway. Any blade which cannot be sheathed and peace-tied will not be permissible, to include but not limited to:  broadaxes, maces, halberds, claymores, pikes or spears. Arrows with tips are not allowed. Drawing of any type of weapons at any time is not allowed and will result in immediate removal from the festival. Are discounts available for attending multiple days? Catch all the fun and excitement by purchasing multi-day flex passes to the Sarasota Medieval Fair!  Discounted Multi-Day Passes purchased online must be picked-up at the Passholder Booth during the festival with Photo ID. Photo ID (and the flex pass that will be issued to you at the Passholder Booth) must be presented at the Castle entrance-way to gain entry to the festival each day.  For all the details and to purchase Multi-Day passes, please visit our ticketing page. Can we bring our pet into the festival? Under applicable law: no pets are allowed at the festival, this includes emotional support animals.  Only service animals are permitted to assist an individual with a disability (details below).  We kindly ask that pets not be brought into the festival as there are many sensitive furry creatures to be found around the festival including the rescues from our birds of prey organizations, petting zoo animals, equestrian performances, camel and pony rides, and many others that can be influenced by pets. We love our furry friends though (we partner with and provide donations to a number of non-profit 501(c)(3) organizations every year, including the Manatee Humane Society)!  Service Animals: A service animal is a dog or miniature horse that is individually trained to do work or perform tasks to assist an individual with a disability. Dogs, miniature horses, or other animals that provide only emotional support, comfort, or companionship are not considered service animals.* A service animal must be under the control of its handler. A service animal must have a harness, leash, or other tether, unless the handler is either unable to use the same because of a disability, or the use of the same would interfere with the service animal’s safe, effective performance of work or tasks. In such case, the service animal must otherwise be under the handler’s control, such as through voice commands, signals, or other effective means.* We ask that non-service animals be removed from the premises. We also ask that service animals that are out of control, pose a threat to health or safety, or are not housebroken be removed from the premises. * U.S. Department of Justice. ADA Requirements: Service Animals. ADA.gov. Last modified February 24, 2020. Are group rates available? Group tickets are available in advance at a discounted rate for groups of 20 or more. Please email: Info@SarasotaMedievalFair.com or call Toll-Free: 1-888-303-FAIR(3247) for details. What is included with the admission price? All 100+ shows daily, including the Jousting Tournaments and Human Combat Chess Matches, and the FREE Children's Realm are included with the cost of admission.  Parking is always Free. Festival souvenirs, arts and crafts, food, beverages, games, and rides are optional and an additional cost. Can we bring food or drink into the festival? Outside food and drinks are not allowed in the festival.  Food and beverage stands are conveniently located throughout the festival. Hard and soft coolers, glass containers, food such as sandwiches, meals, snacks etc., and flavored drinks may not be taken into the park. Water bottles may be taken into the park. Can we re-enter the festival later the same day? Absolutely! If you need to leave the park and re-enter the same day, simply have your hand stamped at the Castle Entranceway. Are debit & credit cards accepted, or is the festival cash only? Debit and credit cards are accepted at the gate at our ticket booth, and with some craft vendors, however most craft vendors, food and beverage vendors, and rides and game vendors only accept cash.  ATM's are conveniently located throughout the festival. Is the festival handicapped accessible? The festival is an outdoor event, held in a natural park-like setting.  Wheelchairs and motorized wheelchairs are welcome and the park is generally wheelchair friendly/accessible.  Pathways vary from grass, light mulch, small rock paths, and dirt with minor rolling elevation changes.  Handicapped parking and handicapped-sized portable restrooms are available.  Guests are welcome to use their own wheelchairs or single passenger ECV's. Do you rent wheelchairs or wagons? We do not currently rent wheelchairs, ECV's, or wagons at this time. What happens if it rains? The Sarasota Medieval Fair remains open during inclement weather, although some of the festivals shows, games, and rides may be temporarily affected or cancelled. Refunds and rain checks will not be issued due to inclement weather. It is extremely rare that we close on a festival day.  The festival is open rain or shine. How can I get involved with the festival? The Sarasota Medieval Fair is always looking for talented performers, volunteers, and merchants to join in on the fun! Please visit our Join the Fun page. Is smoking allowed? For the comfort of all of our guests, smoking of tobacco, e-cigarettes or other products that produce a vapor or smoke are allowed only in designated areas.  These areas are notated on the festival map. How long does it take to see everything? With over 100+ shows held daily, themed weekends, and unique acts each weekend, not everything can be experienced in one day!  We recommend considering a multi-day pass to enjoy all the unique festivities the festival has to offer. Can I bring my drone to the festival? Drones are not permitted at the Sarasota Medieval Fair Are there shows suitable for children? Yes! We have a variety of shows that are especially good for children. Kids can also be made a knight or lady of the realm at the Knighting Ceremony held daily, and make sure to visit our free Children's Realm!  Check the stage schedules for exact performance dates & show times.  Acts are indicated on the festival program as to whether they are rated Family Friendly or rated PG 13. Can we use Uber/Lyft? There are a very limited number of Uber and Lyft drivers available in our area. Please ensure the ride back to your destination is booked and confirmed if you choose to use them for transportation. We have had guests encounter issues with pickup for return trips. Do you host weddings or private parties? Yes, we absolutely do.  Please visit our Royal Weddings page under the 'Join the Fun' tab.  Venue rentals for weddings and private parties are also available throughout the year at the Woods of Mallaranny at Mallaranny Farms, contact us! Do Pub Crawl add-ons include entry to the festival? A ticket to the Pub Crawl does not include admission to the Sarasota Medieval Fair. Guests desiring to join our Pub Crawl experience will need both an admission ticket/pass to the festival and a Pub Crawl ticket to join the Pub Crawl. Skip the long pub lines and join our riotous Pub Crawl with toasts, songs, and entertainment as you explore our festival while making rotating stops at our three main pubs to sample our most tasteful meads, our finest beers/ciders, and our delightful wines. All while in the company of some of our villages most colorful characters.  Tastings include one flight of beer, one flight of mead, and one flight of wine and a big pour of your favorite, OR three big pours of your choice.  For all the details and to make your Pub Crawl reservation, please visit our ticketing page. Do VIP Royal Treatment add-ons include entry to the festival? VIP Add-Ons do not include admission to the festival. The VIP Royal Treatment!  Full Season-long (all 10 festival days) access to our new VIP tent, reserved seating, reserved VIP parking, and VIP only perks & snacks! VIP Add-On's are limited and are available for purchase online.  An excellent value when visiting multiple days or if you just want an exclusive VIP experience!  Or consider a 1-Day VIP Add-on.  VIP Add-On tickets must be redeemed, with Photo ID, at the VIP Tent (located inside the park - consult the festival map). For all the details and to purchase VIP add-ons, please visit our ticketing page. Lost & Found Lost & Found:  Visit the Information stand near the front entranceway to report lost children.  Visit the front entrance Admissions Booth for lost and found items. The Sarasota Medieval Fair, Inc. is not responsible for lost, missing or stolen personal property. With any Lost & Found inquiries, please email Info@SarasotaMedievalFair.com. Include any relevant information on the item that was lost, and the date which you visited the festival and a representative from festival will correspond with you via email. Stay Connected Subscribe *By submitting this form, you are consenting to receive marketing emails from: Sarasota Medieval Fair, 29847 FL-70 E, Myakka City, FL 34251, http://www.SarasotaMedievalFair.com. You can revoke your consent to receive emails at any time by using the unsubscribe link, found at the bottom of every email. Emails are serviced by Brevo. Home · Contact Us · Terms & Conditions © Sarasota Medieval Fair, Inc. - All rights reserved

Sarasota building official resigns amid turmoil over medieval fair News Sports Ticket Lifestyle Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals SARASOTA Sarasota building official resigns amid turmoil over Sarasota Medieval Fair work Timothy Fanning Sarasota Herald-Tribune SARASOTA COUNTY — Sarasota County’s top building official, under investigation by various agencies for her involvement in developing a new home for the Sarasota Medieval Fair , has resigned. The Planning and Development Services department accepted Kathleen Croteau’s resignation on May 12. Neither Croteau or her supervisor explained the reason for her departure, though it appears that she was forced out. “Per our discussion, I am resigning my position effective today,” Croteau told Planning and Development Services director Matt Osterhoudt in a May 12 letter. Croteau’s involvement with the new 50-acre site for the Sarasota Medieval Fair off State Road 70 in Myakka City has drawn scrutiny from both the Florida Department of Transportation and the Manatee County Inspector General’s Office. In case you missed it: Sarasota Medieval Fair moving to Manatee County In other news: Sarasota County board gets earful over voter-approved election initiative Records also show that Croteau routinely performed work duties associated with the massive land clearing and construction project at 29641 State Road 70. She reportedly used her county-issued vehicle to travel to and from the project while on the clock, which is against county policy. Croteau did not respond to phone calls requesting comment. A county spokeswoman declined to make Osterhoudt available for an interview or respond to questions about the resignation. “Sarasota County does not comment on employees' personal matters,” said spokeswoman Brianne Grant. Croteau replaced Greg Yantorno in 2011 after the Herald-Tribune revealed that he illegally waived fees that cost the government at least $7.4 million in uncollected revenue. She earned $111,800 annually. Guy McCauley, the deputy building inspector, will lead the department on an interim basis. Construction on the Medieval Fair site began last fall. Michael Gallen, the general counsel for the Manatee County Inspector General’s Office, said he could not comment about the investigation because it is still active. He said the probe began in late March in response to complaints from residents and reporting by the Bradenton Herald . The newspaper reported how investigators are looking into how Manatee’s code enforcement office did not properly investigate complaints about construction on the property. Because the property owners are family members of Croteau and her son Jeremy Croteau, code enforcement officials allegedly ignored un-permitted work. Kathleen Croteau’s name is on driveway permits submitted to FDOT, records show. In April, FDOT began investigating how a permit was issued for minor improvements to the fair’s entrance off SR 70. Croteau, whose name is on the permit, reportedly withheld the true scope of work on the driveway, telling the state transportation agency that the narrow driveway would be used for residential purposes. The fair typically draws about 20,000 people a year. The investigation that concluded earlier this month said that she would have to submit a new permit application, according to an agency spokesman. After being held for 15 years in the Ringling Woods behind the Sarasota Fairgrounds, the annual Sarasota Medieval Fair announced in October that it found a permanent home at the newly named “Woods of Mallaranny.” That’s the name of the 50-acre SR 70 property owned by Mallaranny LLC . Jeremy Croteau manages the company and is the president of the fair. The property was purchased in September, records show. Construction, which began in the fall, is to create a permanent home that will create “an entire medieval village that’s only limited by our imaginations and dreams,” according to a news release about the project. Timothy Fanning covers Sarasota government for the Herald-Tribune. Reach Timothy at tim.fanning@heraldtribune.com or on Twitter: @timothyjfanning. Support the Herald-Tribune by subscribing today. All rights reserved.

20th Sarasota Medieval Fair kicks off this weekend in Myakka City News Sports Ticket Lifestyle Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals LOCAL 20th annual Sarasota Medieval Fair kicks off this weekend at Woods of Mallaranny farm Sarasota Herald-Tribune 20 th Sarasota Medieval Fair kicks off at Mallaranny farm The 20 th Sarasota Medieval Fair kicks off on Saturday with a month of family-friendly activities at the 47-acre Woods of Mallaranny farm located at 29847 State Road 70 East in Myakka City. Fve full full weekends of events include local artisans and craft demonstrations; performers (including jousting and human chess matches); famous turkey legs; the Children’s Realm; rides and games; and vendors (including nonprofit organizations supporting charities helping with hurricane recovery). Tickets are available for a single day, two-day flex pass, or season pass. The VIP Royal Treatment and Pub Crawl tickets are also back. For details and tickets, visit SarasotaMedievalFair.com . The Woods of Mallaranny on S.R. 70 is approximately 13 miles east of I-75 (across from Dakin Farms). Junior League of Sarasota plans 11th 'Bright Nights' fundraiser The Junior League of Sarasota will hold their 11th annual Bright Nights Fashion Show & Cocktail Party fundraiser on Nov. 16 at the Grove Restaurant and Ballroom in Lakewood Ranch. Bright Nights is the signature fundraiser for the Junior League with all proceeds supporting the organization’s programs to improve the lives of women, children, and families in Sarasota. This year’s event offers an expanded focus on local fashion and design, featuring exclusive collections from four local boutiques, including Simply Jo's, Camilyn Beth, and Marmalade. “This event is a great opportunity to not only enjoy an evening of fashion and fun but also to give back to the community we all care about so deeply,” event chair Angie Gress said. For tickets, visit sarasota.jl.org/events/register-bright-nights-tickets . United Way South Sarasota canceling celebrity softball The United Way of South Sarasota County has canceled the Celebrities & Heroes Softball Game and Concert that was scheduled on Nov. 16 at CoolToday Park in North Port. The United Way said in a press release that its focus will be on hurricane recovery efforts. "We are deeply saddened by this cancellation as we know how hard everyone has worked to make this event possible," said Barbara Cruz, president of United Way of South Sarasota County. "Given the severity of these disasters, our priority must be the well-being of our community." Tickets will be automatically refunded at the point of purchase. No action will be required from ticket-holders but Ticketmaster refunds may take 4-6 weeks to process. For questions or concerns, or if your ticket was purchased at the CoolToday Park box office, contact 941-413-5004 for assistance. For additional questions, call the United Way of South Sarasota County at 941-484-4811. Around and about · Wellen Park will support the Florida Disaster Fund during its First Friday concert on Nov. 1 (6-10 p.m.) by matching donations up to $10,000 through a grant from parent company Mattamy Homes. The event will feature dance band No Filter in Downtown Wellen. wellenpark.com/events . · The Gulf Gate Business District is launching a monthly street festival on Nov. 8 from 4-8 p.m. featuring shops, food, and beverages. The event will continue on the second Friday of each month. · Vets for Vets in Venice is hosting a free concert honoring veterans and their families on Nov. 9 from 2-9 p.m. at Centennial Park, 200 W. Venice Ave. The event, organized by Navy veteran Paul Kaldy, will feature multiple live performances by veteran musicians. Tickets: Eventbrite . · The Women’s Interfaith Network is hosting a program , "A Holy Shakeup! A Woman’s Journey to Equality in Her Church," on Nov. 9 at 10:30 a.m. at Oakhurst Clubhouse, 4255 Oakhurst Circle East, in Sarasota. Rev. Bridget Mary Meehan of the Association of Roman Catholic Women Priests will lead a dialogue/Q&A. Register at melamarcus777@gmail.com. womensinterfaithnetwork.org . · The Women's Guild at St. Mary Star of the Sea , 4280 Gulf of Mexico Drive, in Longboat Key will hold its annual Christmas Bazaar at the Parish Hall on Nov. 9 (10 a.m. to 2 p.m.) and 10 (after 10:30 a.m. Mass). Proceeds will go to hurricane relief efforts. stmarylbk.org . · The inaugural Wellen Park Wine Festival is Nov. 15-16 in Downtown Wellen with more than 30 vintners and wine importers. Vendors will feature vintages from famous national and international wine-producing regions. Tickets: wellenpark.com/wine . · The second annual Sarasota Slam Pickleball Tournament on Nov. 16 at Pompano Park is donating a portion of its proceeds to All Faiths Food Bank. Last year’s event raised $8,000 for Sarasota High School student athletes. For information, including sponsorships, contact Jennifer Stutler at jstutler@stutlerstrategies.com or register a team at tinyurl.com/4bac3fbx . · Vendors and organizations are invited to join the Notjusta Craft Fair on Nov. 16 at Gulf Cove United Methodist Church, 1100 S. McCall Road, in the Gulf Cove area of Port Charlotte. For information, call 302-563-4479. Submissions by Charles Walker, Edie Ousley, Elise Lipoff Ramer, Barbara Cruz, Emily Ford, Sharon Kunkel, Fatima Soriano, Paul Kaldy, Susan Keal, Jonell Yoeckel, Jennifer Hamilton, Kate De Michieli, and Dana Hanson.
